awd_titl_txt: Developing an Industrial Maintenance Technician Pathway to an Advanced Technology Degree
awd_abstract_narration:
The Oklahoma Employment Security Commission predicts a 7.5% annual growth in Mechanical Engineering Technician jobs and a 10% annual growth in Industrial Machinery Mechanic jobs. To help meet these needs, this project will develop an Industrial Maintenance Technician pathway to prepare engineering technicians who have electromechanical experience. This project will develop a Business and Industry Leadership Team with representatives from electromechanical and manufacturing industries to ensure the pathway meets the needs of local employers. With this guidance, faculty will update the existing curriculum, acquire new instructional equipment, and provide students with flexible access to the existing fabrication laboratory. These changes are expected to raise enrollment, retention, and graduation rates of Engineering Technology and Electronics Technology students. Through targeted outreach and mentoring, this project also aims to increase the percentage of female students seeking technical certificates or degrees. 

The goal of the project is to increase and broaden participation in the college's technology degrees to meet the local demand for electromechanical technicians. The specific aims designed to achieve this goal include: 1) implementing a new industrial maintenance technician pathway to increase student enrollment, retention, and graduation rates; 2) developing a flexible learning lab to meet student needs; 3) expanding industry involvement to promote career paths for students; and 4) assessing success of the project and disseminating project outcomes and lessons learned. Curriculum improvements will include developing courses in non-destructive testing and industrial robotics, and revision of courses in motor controls, programmable logic controls, and hydraulics and pneumatics. The new pathway will use stackable credentials that allow entry at each level of the pathway, thus serving students who need specialized training to immediately enter the workforce and students who need to start with the basics. The nationally recognized training track of Certified Production Technician will be embedded as a vital first step. With the Business and Industry Leadership Team in place, industry partners will be intimately involved with the program’s design, and will enrich the program by providing speakers, industry tours, and other resources. The results of the project, curriculum, and pathway will be disseminated with regional and national partners. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Developing an Industry Maintenance Technician Pathway to an Advanced Technology Degree

The project goal was to focus on increasing student interest and broadening local participation in careers specializing in electromechanical circuits or as an industrial maintenance technician. This goal was in response to the Oklahoma Employment Security Commission predicting a 7.5% annual growth in Mechanical Engineering Technician jobs and a 10% annual growth in Industrial Machinery Mechanic jobs.  To achieve those goals, Tulsa Community College partnered with our industry advisors and evaluated trends to develop a pipeline of skilled workers, recruit entry level manufacturing employees in underrepresented areas, and  provide additional technical training to those already in the manufacturing pipeline for consideration to an advanced technician job. To support those goals, the following actions were successfully completed.

  • Flexible class schedules along with on-line content was developed to fit industry needs in Automation, Electronics, Fabrication, and Manufacturing which more than 50% of the students participated in a blended format from 2020 to 2022.
  • Our current advisory committees from Manufacturing and Electronics was expanded to form a larger BILT (Business and Industry Leadership Team) committee which have shown to increase industry involvement with community college programs. Our net industry participation rate increased 200%.
  • A certificate pathway called IMTec (Industrial Maintenace Technician) was created which  focused on industry specific courses which led to work ready employment with less than 17 hours of course work.  
  • We meet our goal of increasing female student enrollments and graduation rates by 20%.

With BILT guidance, faculty updated the existing curriculum, acquired new instructional equipment in Robotics and Non-Destructive Testing (NDT), and provided students with 14 hours of flexible access per day to the existing fabrication laboratory. Faculty equipment training also took place using the latest products used in industry although the training was completed over the three-year time frame due to COVID pandemic travel restrictions.

Promoting the career pathways to new students was another major goal of the grant and included area high schools and those already working in entry level manufacturing jobs. The first two years of program outreach were a challenge due to the same travel restrictions. However, we managed to use on-line outlets, commercials, emails, and YouTube with positive outcomes. Over the course of the three-year grant, Electronics and Manufacturing enrollments have increased while graduation rates for degrees and certificates increased from 14 students in 2020 to 35 students in 2023.  The PI was able to present the project outcomes and lessons learned at three conferences and  TCC has committed to increase student outreach efforts and continue to train technician STEM faculty.

 


Last Modified: 04/23/2024
Modified by: Thomas Henderson
